div.head: The Chronicon
div.p: The Chronicon is a universal history composed by Archbishop of Salerno Romualdus II Guarna shortly before his death (1181). For the period going from Adam until 1125, Romualdus compiled previous sources, possibly working on a previous compilation (see paragraph 'Authenticity' below), while for contemporary events his work is a first hand source. In particular, Romualdus was one of the protagonists of the "Peace of Venice" (1177), a treaty between Emperor Frederick I, Pope Alexander III and other political entities of the Italian area, covered in great detail in the last part of the Chronicon. In fact, Romualdus was a leading figure of the delegation sent by King William II of Sicily to the negotiations in Venice.

div.head: Structure of the work
div.p: The Chronicon initially follows ancient Jewish, Greek and and Roman ancient history, then European (continental and Byzantine) events. It then includes a digression on the the story of the Lombards and the Franks until Louis the Pious (from paragraph g108.24-109.5 i.e. page 108 of Garufi's edition, line 24, to par. g159.9-159.25). From this point on, the scope of the narrative returns to be wide, continental, but it progressively focusses on Southern Italy, until it substantially becomes a chronicle of its Norman conquest and then of the Kingdom of Sicily, ending with the detailed account of the Peace of Venice (from par. v-b298a of the present edition to the end of the work). On the structure and the sources of the work, see Zabbia 2004, 380-383.

div.head: Authorship: textual evidence
Authorship: hypotheses
div.p: For Matthew 1981, the first note only proves that the scribe who wrote it believed in Romualdus' authorship, and the second that the report of the Peace of Venice was based on the archbishop's, possibly written, testimony. Mattews discusses numerous arguments in favor of the thesis that the author of the Chronicon is not Romualdus: he suggests that around 1126 an anonymous compiler based in the Apulian city of Troia wrote a compilation of universal history reporting events until 1125 (see Matthew 1981, 239-256); later, "a writer from Salerno decided to set down the events of the reigns to Roger II and the two Williams in 1177", while only the report of the Peace of Venice "is taken from the written, eitiwness, and true account of Archbishop Romuald" (Matthew 1981, 269-270).

Zabbia 2004 confuted Mattew's arguments and suggested, that Romualdus is the author of the whole work, though he does not rule out the possibility, based on the first note mentioned above ("Ab hoc loco adiunctum est...', par. g213.1-213.8), that the archbishop continued a previously existing universal chronicon. In his view, the note "Ab hoc loco..." simply suggests that "sino al 1125 l'arcivescono avrebbe condotto il suo lavoro sulle fonti; dopo quella data – a partire cioè da quando Romualdo aveva all'incirca quindici anni – il racconto sarebbe fondato sulla memoria dell'autore" (§ metti qui la pag. di zabbia in cui la dice: mi pare, 389).

For Zabbia, this pre-existing 'chronica' is a collective denomination for the sources that Romualdus summarized or copied, though he adds: "Tutto ciò non consente di escludere che l'arcivescono potesse disporre di una cronaca in cui almeno parte del materiale fosse già organizzata" (Zabbia 2004, 389). I incline towards the latter hypothesis, though I agree with Zabbia that Romualdus himself probably conducted or coordinated the final editorial work on the whole Chronicon.

div.head: Manuscripts
div.p:
Another important witness is:
O: a fragment of MS Ottobonianus Latinus 2940, folios 16r-18v, available in https://digi.vatlib.it/mss/detail/Ott.lat.2940.
The importance of O lies in the fact that Schwartz [§ add year] argued that it might be copied from a lost MS, older than A.

The siglum used by Schwartz and other scholars for it is 'Aa'. I am modifying it to 'O' for consistency with the other sigla (one letter only, not including character 'A' already used for Vat. Lat. 3973), thus facilitating the processing of XML files.

div.head: Print editions
div.p: The two most recent print editions of the Chronicon are Garufi 1914 and Bonetti 2001, described in the 'sourceDesc' of this TEI XML file.

div.head: Paragraph identifiers
div.p: Paragraphs ('p' elements in the TEI XML source) have been labelled with @xml:id attributes based on Garufi. For instance, paragraph 'g163.1-163.5' goes from page 163, line 1 to page 163, line 5 of the Garufi edition. In some cases, Garufi's paragraphs have been further broken into smaller 'p' elements to facilitate collation.

div.head: Sigla
div.p: As noted in the 'sourceDesc' element, in the @wit attributes of 'lem' and 'rdg' elements I used sigla 'g' for Garufi', 'b' for Bonetti, 'a' for MS A (first hand), 'a2' for the second hand of MS A (probably XVII century) and 'o' for the fragment of MS O.

front.head: Long and short versions of the work
front.p: MSS B and C present a number of textual passages absent in A and O. We thus distinguish between a 'long' (MSS B and C) and 'short' version of the work (A and O). Those additions correspond to paragraphs: §§§ insert list

div.head: Second hand in A
div.p: MS A, as mentioned above, has the 'short' version, and other parts that probably were originally present in the codex were later lost due to physical damage. Someone, probably in the XVII century, integrated MS A with the missing parts, by writing them in the marginal space or by adding extra folios. I transcribed and collated the following portions of MS A added by the second hand and marked their readings with siglum 'a2' in 'app' elements: g180.10-180.12, g180.13-180.15, g181.1-181.1, g181.2-181.5, g181.6-181.10, g181.10-181.11, 81.12-182.19, g183.1-184.6, g184.7-184.9, g184.10-184.13, g186.6-186.7, g186.8-186.8, 86.9-186.9, g187.5-187.8, g187.11-187.14, g188.5-188.7, g189.1-189.1, g191.3-191.5, 95.6-195.8, g198.4-198.5, g198.12-198.13, g198.16-198.17, g199.5-199.8, g200.17-200.21, 01.19-201.20, g202.7-202.10, g203.1-203.2, g203.6-203.6, g206.13-206.17, g208.1-208.9, 10.23-210.24, g211.15-211.17, g212.5-212.9, g212.10-212.11, g212.12-212.13, g213.1-213.8, 14.12-214.14, g214.14-215.3, g219.3-219.4, g214.n8-215.n14, g216.n10-217.n1, g217.n4-217.n10, 18.n16-218.n23, g219.n1-219.n13, g217.n10-218.n16, g234.n1-236.n10.

front.div:
Aim
The present edition aims at improving the text of the Chronicon by Romualdus Salernitanus (Romualdus II Guarna) through a new collation of the text of the print editions of Garufi and Bonetti against A and O, the main witnesses of the 'short version' of the work
Full details on manuscripts and print editions of the work are in § [§§§ biblio su prine editions e MSS: vd. altro §§§]

div.head: Paragraphs in Garufi and Bonetti
div.p: I already mentioned that portion of the work is included in Bonetti. Garufi has the wole text, including the additions that distinuish the 'long' from the 'short' version (though he mostly publishes those additions in apparatus notes), but does not have the report of the Peace of Venice, i.e. paragraphs from v-b298c through v-b306b. This is why their @xml:id does not start with 'g'. Bonetti includes the Peace of Venice, with Arndt's text. [sbagliato, cambiare §]

div.head: Paragraphs missing in A and O
div.p: Some paragraphs are missing both in MS A (first or second hand) and in MS O, so for them I am simply reporting the text of Garufi or Bonetti (i.e. Garufi/Arndt), without any 'app' elements. These paragraphs are those of the Peace of Venice, plus the following: g74.21-74.21, g85.20-85.30, g85.31-86.12, g86.13-86.25, g86.26-87.29, g87.30-88.28, 8.29-90.15, g90.16-90.20, g90.21-92.5, g92.6-92.7, g92.8-92.9, g179.10-179.11, 86.10-186.11, g187.3-187.4, g199.13-199.15, g206.n4-206.n5, g215.n14-216.n10.

div.head: GitHub
div.p: The source code of this edition, including transcriptions of the witnesses and Python software, is in the project GitHub repository https://github.com/paolomonella/romualdus.

div.head: Collation exemplars
div.p: Garufi was the collation exemplar for the first part of the work, from the incipit through paragraph g163.1-163.5. Bonetti was the collation exemplar for the part of the text it includes, i.e. from paragraph g163.6-163.7 to the end of the text. The legibility of the print in Bonetti's edition is better than in Garufi's, so it lends itself to less error-prone OCR. This is the reason why I decided to use Bonetti as collation exemplar for this part of the work.

div.head: Bonetti
div.p: Bonetti uses Garufi's edition as "testo base", and Arndt (Arndt, W., ed. 1866, Romoaldi II archiepiscopi Salernitani Annales, Vol. SS XIX, Hannover) as "elemento integrativo" (see 'Nota al testo', Bonetti 2001, 56). Thus Bonetti's text can be considered mostly equivalent to that of Garufi. However, in the part of the text collated against Bonetti (g163.1-163.5 to the end), whenever I chose the reading of a MS against that of Bonetti, and the text of Garufi diverged from that fo Bonetti, I recorded both Garufi's and Bonetti's readings in the 'app' element.

div.head: Parts for collation
Transpositions
div.p: In part 2-bravo, the order of the paragraphs diverges between Garufi, Bonetti and MS A, do to a number of large transpositions of those paragraphs in the manuscripts. I chose the order of Bonetti.

div.head: Transcription layers
div.p: I transcribed all witnesses at the 'alphabetic layer', but I provided a sample 'graphematic layer' transcription of the first paragraphs of MSS A, B and C, available in the edition GitHub repository. See Monella 2018 (DOI: 10.6092/issn.2532-8816/7286) for a definition of those layers of representation of the text in primary sources. For paragraphs from g116.6-118.8 through g163.1-163.5 I only transcribed major variants.

div.head: Normalization
Variant types and subtypes
div.p: I added a @type attribute to all 'app' elements, and a @subtype attribute to some. Custom Python scripts proposed the values of those attributes, then I reviewed them all manually.

div.head: List of variant types
div.p:
Attribute @type of 'app' can take one of the following values:
'substantive'
'orthographic'
'punctuation'
'gap-in-ms'
'illegible-in-ms'
'transposition'

div.head: Variant subtypes
Variants for which many subtypes apply
div.p: For some variants (i.e. for some 'app' elements), it is impossible to determine one subtype, either because two subtypes apply (e.g., for Symmachus/Simachus 'y' and 'double') or because there are three readings with different types and/or subtypes (e.g. Pisa, Bonetti / Pysas, MS A / Pisas, MS O: Pisa/Pysas is ubstantive' variant, but Pysas/Pisas is an 'orthographic'/'y' variant). I took a pragmatic (and certainly debatable) approach to this issue, as I chose what I thought was the most relevant type/subtype: for example, I chose subtype 'y' for Symmachus/Simachus and type 'substantive' for Pisa/Pysas/Pisas.

div.head: Distinction between substantive and orthographic
div.p: Also, the line between 'substantive' and 'orthographic' variants is thin. This is particularly evident for proper nouns, for which the change of one letter can be considered meaningful. This is why for proper nouns I tended to choose @type='substantive', except for the most common orthographic subtypes, such as 'double' (Callixtus/Calixtus), 'y' (Babyloniam/Babiloniam) or 'h' (Hieronymo/Ieronimo).

div.head: Case variants
div.p: Some 'app' elements mark a distinction between the lowercase and capitalized spelling of the same word: these elements have @type="orthographic" with @subtype="case". For example, 'Cainan' (my lemma) vs cainan (reading of Garufi and of MS A). MSS will always have the lowercase spelling by convention, because capitalization does not have graphematic value in them. Those 'app' elements mean that I capitalize a word that was in lowercase in the print edition, or vice versa.

div.head: Punctuation variants
div.p: The case of punctuation is similar to the preceding one. I chose not to transcribe the MSS punctuation, so all 'app' elements with type="punctuation" mean that I am modifying the punctuation of the print edition (of the collation exemplar for that part of the text). For example, I deleted all quotation marks from the Bonetti edition, but sometimes punctuation modification implies significant differences in phrase and sentence segmentation, therefore in syntax and text interpretation.
